title: (x) One classic serif, one Victorian display font - Infidelity Pro {Michael A}, various alternatives {Mike Y}
content:
Greetings,

Looking to ID the tiny serif (geesh, could it be any $%#@! smaller?) in this Muccatype ad that reads, "Fine letterforms & moustache twirling":

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202042107im_/http:/typophile.com/files/moustache_6406.jpg)

Also looking to ID the Victorian era display font used on the two tiny images of "Staehle" and "Rio".

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202042107im_/http:/typophile.com/files/staehle_4797.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202042107im_/http:/typophile.com/files/rio_6076.jpg)

Many thanks!
author: malbright

comments.content:
I think Infidelity Pro might be correct.

Cheers.
Now if we can just nail the other one ...

I searched using "1800s" at MyFonts and came up with one fair candidate that looks like a flattened version of your typeface: [Flatrock](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202042107/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/flatrock/) from Font Mesa. It came closest to having the strange geometry of your sample lettering. Dan Solo (Solotype) also had a number of fonts recreating typestyles from this era that had a similar feeling, but not the angular "O": Riviera, Houdini, Penny Arcade and Dawson (all at MyFonts).

- Mike Yanega
